questions.text:
Among the given statements, which one would lead you to consider primary amenorrhea as a possibility? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
  2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
  3. High levels of TSH and short stature
  4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation in a girl who has not attained menarche by a certain age or who lacks secondary sexual characteristics. Specifically:

 

1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age: This is a classic indicator of primary amenorrhea, particularly if secondary sexual characteristics have developed. It is an age by which menstruation should have started if there are signs of puberty.

 

2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche: Thelarche, or breast development, typically occurs around ages 9 to 13. If menarche has not occurred within 3 years after thelarche, it is a reason to investigate primary amenorrhea.

 

4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age: The absence of breast development by age 13 indicates a delay in puberty and warrants evaluation for primary amenorrhea if menstruation has not begun by this age.

 

Other Option:

 

3. High levels of TSH and short stature: While high TSH and short stature may indicate thyroid dysfunction or other endocrine issues, they are not direct indicators of primary amenorrhea. These findings might contribute to secondary causes of amenorrhea or other growth disorders but are not themselves diagnostic criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in Hypokalemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Typically, hyperkalemia would show peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, and possibly a flattened P wave, which are not evident in this ECG.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Would more typically show a prolonged QT interval but lacks the specific U wave features seen in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: This condition would likely show a shortened QT interval, which is not present in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

 

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

choices.text: Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance
Stria albicans – Cushing syndrome
Xeroderma pigmentosum – Freckles
Café au lait spots – McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: An overweight 13-year-old girl has the following blackish discoloration on her neck, as shown in the image below. What is this condition and its association? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance

 

Option A.

 

Acanthosis Nigricans:

 

  • This condition is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically found in the intertriginous areas such as the neck, axilla, and groin.
  • The lesion’s appearance in the image is consistent with Acanthosis Nigricans.
  • It is commonly associated with insulin resistance and can be a marker for type 2 diabetes mellitus, especially in the context of overweight or obesity, as seen in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Striae Albicans:

 

  • This refers to the white or silver stretch marks that occur when the skin has been stretched rapidly as in the case of rapid weight gain or with conditions like Cushing syndrome.

 

 

  • However, the image does not show stretch marks but rather a hyperpigmented, thickened area of skin.

 

Option C. Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

 

 

  • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

 

Option D. Café au lait spots:

 

  • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome.

 

 

  • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Acanthosis Nigricans by its velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the neck and its association with insulin resistance in the context of obesity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder where phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, cannot be properly metabolized due to enzyme deficiencies. In classical PKU, the deficiency is in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, if phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are normal, as stated in the question, the problem lies elsewhere in the metabolic pathway. Dihydrobiopterin reductase is an enzyme that regenerates tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor necessary for phenylalanine hydroxylase function. If dihydrobiopterin reductase is deficient, tetrahydrobiopterin cannot be regenerated, leading to non-classical PKU despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of tyrosine, not in the initial conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine or the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin, making it unrelated to PKU.

 

Option C. Dopa decarboxylase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine from DOPA, unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D. Tyrosine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts tyrosine to DOPA and is involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

choices.text: Amyloid light chain (AL)
Amyloid associated protein (AA)

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is more likely to develop in a patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

 

Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis (HAA) is a condition that occurs in patients who have been undergoing long-term hemodialysis, typically for chronic renal failure. The culprit protein in this form of amyloidosis is β2-microglobulin (Aβ2M).

 

β2-microglobulin is a component of MHC class I molecules and is normally filtered out by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, and especially those on long-term dialysis, β2-microglobulin accumulates because it is not efficiently removed by the dialysis membrane. Over time, this accumulation can lead to the deposition of amyloid fibrils composed of Aβ2M in various tissues, particularly around joints, leading to conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome and other forms of osteoarticular amyloidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid light chain (AL): This type of amyloidosis is associated with plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma, where abnormal light chains are produced and deposit as amyloid.

 

Option B. Amyloid associated protein (AA): AA amyloidosis is secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions like tuberculosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or chronic infections, where Serum Amyloid A (SAA) is overproduced and deposits as amyloid.

 

Option D. Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR): ATTR amyloidosis involves transthyretin, a protein produced in the liver, which can form amyloid deposits either due to genetic mutations (familial amyloid polyneuropathies) or in wild-type form, primarily affecting the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure may experience the development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.

 

Additional Information

 

A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis

 

 

B. Localised Amyloidosis

 

 

C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. What is the organism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio cholerae

 

Characteristic features of Vibrio cholera:

 

  • Rice water stool: This is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholerae. The stool looks similar to the water left after washing rice, which is a key indicator of this infection.
  • Darting motility: Vibrio cholerae exhibits a unique form of motility known as darting motility. This type of movement resembles a shooting star, which is rapid and straight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, not characterized by rice water stools or darting motility.

 

Option C. E. coli: While certain strains of E. coli can cause diarrhea, they do not produce rice water stools nor do they exhibit darting motility. Their motility is usually peritrichous flagella-based.

 

Option D. Shigella dysentriae: This pathogen causes dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea, not rice water stools. It also does not exhibit darting motility; its movement is typically more sluggish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of motility:

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

 

An increase in heart rate is the best sign that a ventilatory effort is working.

 

When newborns are unable to breathe on their own, positive pressure ventilation, or PP, is used. To ensure that the airway is open, the infant's neck is slightly stretched in this position. An appropriate-sized face mask is chosen so that it may cover the mouth and nose when the care provider is at the baby's head end. For a good seal, it should be gripped firmly, and compression is applied using the fingers.

 

Visible chest rise is a sign of adequate ventilation, and ventilation should be initiated when normal chest rise is seen.

 

The baby's progress is measured by an increase in heart rate, spontaneous breathing, and improvement in colour.

 

When there is no rise in heart rate, ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows

 

  • Mask has to be reapplied
  • The infant's head is repositioned
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated. Also, the pressure is increased slightly.
  • Change the airway

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is a component of APGAR score

 

Option C. Air entry: Air entry is checked during intubation to check weather the endotracheal tube is in centre which gives equal air entry to both lungs.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Chest rise is also seen once we do bag and mask ventilation but the most important indicator is rising heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows the absence of cranial bones, which are typically visible as white structures on ultrasound. In anencephaly, the forebrain and cranial vault are absent, resulting in a recognizable appearance on ultrasound. Additionally, anencephaly is often associated with prominent eyeballs, known as the "frog eye sign," further supporting this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: This condition presents as a fluid-filled cystic mass, often seen in the neck region. On ultrasound, cystic hygroma appears as a black (anechoic) structure due to its fluid content, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull, usually seen as a sac-like protrusion. This appearance is distinct from anencephaly and involves brain tissue extending outside the cranial cavity, which is not observed here.

 

Option D. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition involves an enlarged posterior fossa with a cystic structure, indicating the presence of a posterior fossa cyst. The ultrasound findings of Dandy Walker malformation are distinct and do not match the current image showing an absence of cranial bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial bones and brain tissue on ultrasound, often accompanied by the "frog eye sign."

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the parameter seen in all types of shock: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Tissue Perfusion

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a constant feature in all types of shock. Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. Regardless of the type, the hallmark of shock is reduced blood flow to the tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery and nutrient supply to meet the cellular needs, leading to cellular and tissue hypoxia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Temperature: Increased temperature or fever is not seen in all types of shock. It is commonly seen in septic shock due to the systemic inflammatory response to infection.

 

Option B. Increased Pulse Pressure: Increased pulse pressure is not a consistent finding in all types of shock. In fact, pulse pressure often narrows in states like hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock.

 

Option C. Increased Peripheral Resistance: Increased peripheral resistance (SVR) is not present in all types of shock. For example, septic and anaphylactic shock are characterized by decreased SVR due to widespread vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a universal characteristic of all types of shock, leading to inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text: Identify the most important risk factor for acute mastitis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cracked nipple
 

The most important risk factor for acute mastitis is the presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples. These openings provide a direct entry point for bacteria, primarily Staphylococcus aureus, which commonly inhabits the oropharynx of the nursing infant. This condition often arises during the first month of breastfeeding when the nipples are most vulnerable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Massage: While massage can sometimes be recommended to alleviate symptoms of engorgement or blocked ducts, improper or overly vigorous massage is not a significant risk factor for developing acute mastitis.

 

Option B. Breast engorgement: Breast engorgement can lead to blocked ducts and potentially contribute to mastitis if milk is not effectively removed, but it is not the most important risk factor compared to cracked nipples.

 

Option C. Lactation failure: Lactation failure can cause issues such as milk stasis and engorgement, which might predispose to infection. However, it is not as direct a risk factor as cracked nipples, which provide a clear pathway for bacterial entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples is the most important risk factor for acute mastitis due to the direct pathway it provides for bacterial entry.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are  associated with a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma 

 

The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Lisch nodules can present as slightly elevated pigmented areas to distinct ball-like nodules over the iris. Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis and not neurofibromatosis.

 

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

 

 

Note:

 

Lisch nodules are seen in NF-1; however, it can also be seen in NF-2 sometimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is seen in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF1.

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Methylmalonyl Co isomerase
  2. Homocysteine synthase
  3. Folate reductase
  4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

Among the given enzymes, methyl malonyl Co isomerase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12 dependent enzymes.

 

Physiologic role of B12

 

  1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase: D-Methyl malonyl CoA is formed in the body from propionyl CoA. It is then converted to L form by a racemase and then isomerized by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (containing Ado-B12) to succinyl CoA, which enters into citric acid cycle. In B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates and methyl malonic aciduria occurs.
  2. Homocysteine Methyl Transferase requires B12 activity to convert homocysteine to methionine.
  3. Methyl Folate Trap and Folate Deficiency - The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step. Therefore, the only way for regeneration of free THFA is step No. 1 in Figure. When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place. This is called the methyl folate trap. This leads to the associated folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

 

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

 

1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase (Methylmalonyl CoA mutase): This enzyme converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a critical step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The enzyme requires adenosylcobalamin (Ado-B12) as a cofactor.

 

4. Methionine Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine using methylcobalamin (Me-B12) as a cofactor. This reaction is crucial for the regeneration of methionine and the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an essential methyl group donor in numerous methylation reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Homocysteine Synthase: There is no enzyme by this specific name, but homocysteine is converted to methionine by methionine synthase, which is vitamin B12-dependent.

 

3. Folate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), an essential step in folate metabolism. However, it does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Study of all aspects of death is called as: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thanatology

 

Thanatology is the scientific study of death, dying, and the processes surrounding them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traumatology: The study of injuries and wounds, including their medical treatment and repair.

 

Option C. Toxicology: The study of the adverse effects of chemicals on living organisms, especially the poisoning effects of drugs and chemicals.

 

Option D. Epidemiology: The study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specific populations and the application of this study to control health problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thanatology is the field that comprehensively studies death and the various aspects associated with it.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. High incidence of spondylolysis in gymnasts and other athlete’s suggest repetitive injury, which may be the contributing mechanism. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage as measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate collar or broken neck on the scottie dog in spondylolysis.

 

 

Collar or broken neck on the scottie dog appearance

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another. It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. The extent of slippage may not be correlated with severity of pain. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).

 

 

Beheaded dog appearance

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive (AR, 11q13) and late onset osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence/adult form) is AD (1P 21). Intermediate form is AR. Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth, resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Fragile, brittle bones, and Pathological fractures are seen. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen on radiograph. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

 

Marble bone appearance

 

 

Rugger jersey spine

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is the radiological feature seen in osteoporosis, called as codfish appearance of vertebra.

choices.text: Review USG after 2 weeks
Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
ECV at 36 weeks
Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
    • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
    • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
    • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.

 

Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

 

Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Match the following microscopic finding with the type of tumor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b  

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid (5HIAA) seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoid syndrome

 

Carcinoid syndrome is the correct answer. It is a condition associated with the overproduction of serotonin by certain tumors, known as carcinoid tumors. Elevated serotonin levels can lead to increased 5HIAA excretion in the urine. This condition is known for causing flushing, diarrhea, and other symptoms.

 

5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is produced in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract. In normal circumstances, most of the serotonin produced in the enterochromaffin cells is metabolized in the liver and then excreted in the urine as 5HIAA. However, in carcinoid syndrome, serotonin-secreting tumors can produce excessive amounts of serotonin that overwhelm the metabolic capacity of the liver, resulting in high levels of urinary 5HIAA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder in which homogentisic acid is not properly metabolized, leading to its accumulation in various tissues and the urine. This condition is not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option B. Albinism is a genetic disorder that results in reduced or absent production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body cannot properly process the amino acid phenylalanine. This results in the accumulation of toxic byproducts that can lead to intellectual disability, seizures, and other serious health problems. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome leads to the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, resulting in increased levels of its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA), in the urine, which is a diagnostic marker for this syndrome.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein and positive India ink staining. What is likely causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Cryptococcus neoformans. The patient presents with signs of meningitis (fever, neck stiffness) and has a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining.

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and is diagnosed by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells seen on India ink staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This organism typically causes pneumonia rather than meningitis.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with low glucose levels in the CSF, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with a neutrophilic CSF rather than lymphocytic CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in HIV patients, characterized by lymphocytic CSF, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining, which reveals encapsulated yeast cells.

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

 ApoB-48 is produced through RNA editing. RNA editing involves the modification of the nucleotide sequence of an RNA molecule, specifically the conversion of a cytosine (C) to a uracil (U) in the mRNA. In the case of ApoB-48, this editing changes a codon, resulting in the synthesis of a shorter protein product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA Alternate Splicing: RNA alternate splicing is a process where different exons (coding regions) of a pre-mRNA are combined in various ways to generate different mature mRNA molecules. This process can result in the production of different protein isoforms, but it is not the mechanism for generating ApoB-48.

 

Option C. DNA Editing: DNA editing typically refers to genetic engineering techniques that modify the DNA sequence, such as CRISPR-Cas9. This is not the process by which ApoB-48 is generated.

 

Option D. RNA Interference: RNA interference (RNAi) is a cellular process involved in gene regulation, where small RNA molecules inhibit gene expression. It does not play a direct role in the synthesis of ApoB-48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg 238

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

This patient is presenting with chronic hypertension that has progressed to superimposed preeclampsia, indicated by the development of 3+ proteinuria, a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg, and symptoms such as headache and blurring of vision. These symptoms and her elevated blood pressure suggest severe preeclampsia.

 

  • Severe Preeclampsia: A systolic blood pressure greater than 160 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 110 mmHg, along with symptoms like headache and visual disturbances, are indicators of severe preeclampsia. In this case, the patients condition requires urgent management to prevent the development of eclampsia, a condition that can lead to seizures and other severe complications.
  • Management: The correct management for severe preeclampsia at 36 weeks gestation includes the administration of Labetalol to lower the blood pressure, Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to prevent seizures, and expedited delivery to resolve the preeclampsia. After 34 weeks of gestation, delivery is recommended for severe preeclampsia because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO4 + Wait till 37 weeks: As this is severe preeclampsia, there is a very high risk waiting till 37 weeks. Immediate delivery is indicated after 34 weeks

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + wait till 37 weeks: There is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks and also there is no indication to wait till 37 weeks as this is severe preeclampsia

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Although delivery needs to be expedited, there is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

A. Zinc chloride:

 

  • Mechanism: Irritant
  • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.

 

B. Chloral hydrate:

 

  • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.

 

C. Quinine:

 

  • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.

 

D. Potassium carbonate:

 

  • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is an essential practice for the care of low birthweight infants, particularly in resource-limited settings. The core components of KMC include:

 

  • Skin-to-skin contact: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The baby's hips are abducted and flexed in a "frog position," and the arms are also flexed. This close contact helps regulate the baby's temperature, breathing, and heart rate.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: KMC promotes exclusive breastfeeding, which is crucial for the baby's nutrition and immune protection.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care: KMC supports the early discharge of stable low birthweight infants from the hospital, allowing continued care at home with close follow-up.

 

These components are fundamental to the success of KMC, leading to improved survival rates and health outcomes for low birthweight infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection," which is an essential aspect of general neonatal care but not a specific component of KMC. KMC primarily focuses on skin-to-skin contact, breastfeeding, and early discharge.

 

Option C. Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Also mentions "prevent infection," which, while important, is not a direct component of KMC.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection" instead of "skin-to-skin contact," making it incorrect, as skin-to-skin contact is a critical element of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called exciting eye and the fellow eye is called sympathising eye.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

choices.text: Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

 

Option A. Droplet digital PCR : Digital Droplet PCR (ddPCR) is known as the third generation of quantitative PCR and is the Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH is a cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences. While it is valuable for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting mutations at low allele frequencies.

 

Option C. Nested PCR: Nested PCR involves two rounds of PCR amplification, with the second round using primers nested within the product of the first round. While it can increase sensitivity, it may not be as quantitative or precise as ddPCR.

 

Option D. Sanger Sequencing: Sanger sequencing is a traditional DNA sequencing method. While it is highly accurate, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting low-frequency mutations. It is more suitable for identifying mutations present at higher allele frequencies.

 

Educational objective:

 

Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR)

 

Principle: Droplet digital PCR is a highly sensitive and quantitative method for detecting and quantifying nucleic acids. It partitions the PCR reaction into thousands of droplets, and each droplet serves as an individual reaction chamber.

 

Advantages: It allows for absolute quantification of DNA with high precision and sensitivity. It is particularly effective in detecting mutations present at low allele frequencies.

 

Application: ddPCR is widely used for detecting rare mutations, monitoring minimal residual disease, and assessing low-abundance targets in various samples.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

C3b functions as an opsonin.

 

Opsonization: - The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.

 

Include:

 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen
  • C3b, C4b, C5b

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. C3a and C. C5a: These are anaphylatoxins involved in inflammation and promoting chemotaxis.

 

Option D. C6: Part of the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

  • Niacin deficiency, specifically pellagra, is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin changes), diarrhea (digestive symptoms), and dementia (neurological symptoms). The symptoms described in the patient match those of pellagra, making niacin deficiency the likely cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, primarily manifests as neurological and cardiovascular symptoms. It is not associated with dermatitis and diarrhea, which are prominent features of pellagra.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, also known as ariboflavinosis, can lead to various symptoms, including sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, and inflammation and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue). While it shares some symptoms with pellagra, such as mucous membrane changes, it does not typically cause dementia and diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine deficiency, also known as vitamin B6 deficiency, can lead to neurological symptoms but does not typically cause dermatitis or diarrhea. It is not the primary deficiency associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major protein of Maize, Zein lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.

 

Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

 

Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.

 

Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: A patient with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis, palpable purpura, myalgia, and pulmonary hemorrhage was found to have p-ANCA positivity. Which of the following is the likely vasculitis in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a type of small-vessel vasculitis that is commonly associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA) positivity.

 

MPA is characterized by multi-organ involvement, including pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis (kidney involvement), palpable purpura (skin involvement), myalgia (muscle involvement), and pulmonary hemorrhage (lung involvement).

 

The presence of p-ANCA is a key diagnostic feature that differentiates MPA from other types of vasculitides.

 

MPA does not usually form granulomas, which is a distinguishing factor from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegeners), another ANCA-associated vasculitis. The constellation of symptoms and p-ANCA positivity points directly toward MPA as the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): This condition is typically associated with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positivity, not p-ANCA. Additionally, GPA often presents with granulomatous inflammation, which is not seen in MPA.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN involves medium-sized arteries and typically spares the lungs. It is not associated with ANCA positivity, and patients with PAN do not usually present with glomerulonephritis or pulmonary hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Behcet disease: This condition is an inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. It is associated with the presence of anti-endothelial or anti-enolase antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis associated with p-ANCA positivity and multi-organ involvement, including the kidneys, skin, muscles, and lungs

 

p-ANCA Positive Conditions:

 

 

Comparison of c-ANCA vs p-ANCA:

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The given picture shows discrete and large speckles in the resting cells, and the alignment of the speckles in the chromosome region in the dividing cells. This is suggestive of centromeric pattern of ANA staining. Centromeric pattern is seen in limited cutaneous sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogenous: The homogenous pattern is characterized by uniform staining of the entire nucleus. It is commonly associated with antibodies against DNA-histone complexes and is seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

 

Option C. Nucleolar: The nucleolar pattern shows staining of the nucleoli within the nucleus. This pattern is typically seen with anti-nucleolar antibodies, which are often associated with systemic sclerosis, particularly the diffuse form.

 

Option D. Speckled: The speckled pattern features fine or coarse speckles distributed throughout the nucleus but sparing the nucleoli. This pattern is associated with a wide range of autoimmune diseases, including SLE, Sjögren's syndrome, and mixed connective tissue disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The centromeric ANA staining pattern is associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) and is characterized by discrete speckles aligned with chromosomes in dividing cells.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.
